summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from SEC whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio, dated between June and October 2020, alleging widespread corruption and criminal obstruction by the SEC and SDNY. Dilorio claims the agencies protect financial entities like Jefferies, Virtu Financial (NITE), and others involved in abusive naked short selling, money laundering via OTC markets, and accounting fraud, while suppressing his whistleblower claims and denying him awards. He specifically references the Dan Kamensky case and implicates numerous financial and political figures.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of SEC/SDNY corruption, obstruction, and protection of financial criminals like Jefferies and Virtu Financial. He references his own TCRs and award denials.

persons.name: Rich Handler
persons.context: Alleged to have a corrupt, criminal relationship with the SEC and SDNY, benefiting from the protection of Jefferies and involvement in the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Douglas Cifu
persons.context: Portrayed as central to the alleged fraud at Virtu/NITE, admitting the importance of retail/OTC volumes to revenue, and involved in the KCG merger and balance sheet manipulation.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused of corruption, conflicts of interest due to his past at Sullivan & Cromwell and friendship with Glenn Hutchins, and failure to recuse himself from matters involving NITE/VIRT.

persons.name: Glenn Hutchins
persons.role: Co-founder of Silver Lake, former Blackstone
persons.context: Described as a good friend of Jay Clayton, involved with Blackstone and the purchase/sale of SunGard, which led to the formation of North Island with Robert Greifeld.

persons.name: Robert Greifeld
persons.context: Former NASDAQ CEO who was a director at Automated Securities Clearance Ltd, which was sold to SunGard. Later formed North Island with Glenn Hutchins, a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT.

persons.name: Adena Friedman
persons.context: Signed off on NASDAQ's acquisition of the BRUT ECN from SunGard, a transaction questioned by Dilorio.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Subject of a joint SEC/SDNY complaint. Dilorio believes exculpatory evidence is being withheld and that Kamensky's case is connected to the corrupt relationship between the SEC/SDNY and Jefferies.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Identified as a Sullivan & Cromwell colleague of Jay Clayton who played a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT operational.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Official (likely in Office of the Whistleblower)
persons.context: Referenced as having denied Dilorio's whistleblower award, with Dilorio accusing her of creating extraordinary reasons for denial and failing to produce the full record.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: Referenced as corrupt and precluded from involvement in investigating Clayton due to alleged SEC corruption.

persons.name: Richard Best
persons.context: Brought a FINRA complaint against Brown Brothers Harriman related to Dilorio's information.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to Hanover/Magna and SEC complaints about bogus notes, detailed in Dilorio's TCRs.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Detailed in Dilorio's 2013 TCR for illegal activity; later barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor' and linked to Blink Charging.

persons.name: Blostein
persons.context: Goldman analyst questioned about his modeling of NITE/VIRT OTC volumes and alleged failure to disclose material facts.

persons.name: Repetto
persons.context: Sell-side analyst referenced in questions about NITE/VIRT and the corrupt relationship with Jefferies.

persons.name: Fannon
persons.context: Sell-side analyst referenced alongside Repetto in questions about NITE/VIRT.

persons.name: Berger
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's 2013 TCR filing.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Addressed by Dilorio, applauded for reproof of the SDNY, and urged to look at the Dan Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Addressed by Dilorio regarding the corrupt SEC/Handler/NITE relationship and the Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Jones
persons.context: Addressed by Dilorio regarding proof of SEC corruption and the ongoing fraud on the courts.

persons.name: Crede
persons.context: Linked to Net Element, Esousa, and Cobblestone in alleged money laundering schemes.

persons.name: Peizer
persons.context: Linked to Net Element, Esousa, and Cobblestone in alleged money laundering schemes.

persons.name: Milken
persons.context: Linked to Net Element, Esousa, and Cobblestone in alleged money laundering schemes.

persons.name: Ajay Tandon
persons.context: Named in an SEC complaint for pump-and-dump promotions related to Net Element.

persons.name: Amit Tandon
persons.context: Named in an SEC complaint for pump-and-dump promotions related to Net Element.

connections.description: Dilorio alleges a corrupt, criminal relationship where the SEC and SDNY protect Handler and Jefferies from investigation and prosecution.
Described as good friends, with Clayton allegedly protecting interests related to Hutchins's investments (North Island, NITE/VIRT).
Partners in forming North Island, which became a top shareholder in the alleged criminal enterprise NITE/VIRT.
Alleged co-conspirators in orchestrating the VIRT/KCG merger and manipulating balance sheets to hide insolvency.
Colleagues from Sullivan & Cromwell; Fishman allegedly played a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT operational.
Whistleblower alleging the SEC actively obstructed his claims, denied awards improperly, and failed to produce records.
Kamensky is a defendant in a case where Jefferies is the investment bank; Dilorio suggests exculpatory evidence implicating Jefferies is being withheld.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: The trading glitch at Knight Capital that revealed insolvency and led to a bailout, alleged by Dilorio to be a cover-up for ongoing naked short selling and accounting fraud.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: The $1.4 billion all-cash merger of KCG Holdings and Virtu Financial, alleged to be fraudulent, with KCG insolvent and its balance sheet manipulated with SEC complicity.

events.title: Dilorio's Allegation of Ongoing Insolvency
events.description: Dilorio claims NITE/VIRT remains insolvent due to ongoing abusive naked short selling and money laundering, with the SEC facilitating the fraud.

events.title: SEC Complaint Against SeeThruEquity
events.description: SEC filed a complaint against SeeThruEquity, LLC and the Tandon brothers for pump-and-dump schemes related to Net Element (NETE), which Dilorio had alerted them to.

events.title: FINRA Bar of Justin Keener/JMJ
events.description: FINRA barred Justin Keener/JMJ as a 'Bad Actor' for failing to comply with investigations into money laundering via OTC shells.

keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio, an SEC whistleblower, alleges a vast, corrupt relationship between the SEC/SDNY and financial entities like Jefferies (Rich Handler) and Virtu Financial (Douglas Cifu), claiming they protect these firms from investigation into abusive naked short selling, OTC market money laundering, and accounting fraud.

Dilorio implicates then-SEC Chairman Jay Clayton in corruption, citing undisclosed conflicts of interest from his time at Sullivan & Cromwell and his friendship with Glenn Hutchins, and alleges Clayton failed to recuse himself from matters involving NITE/VIRT.

The document details specific alleged frauds: the 2012 Knight Capital 'glitch' and 2017 VIRT/KCG merger are portrayed as cover-ups for insolvency and balance sheet manipulation, with the SEC actively obstructing investigations and whistleblower awards.

Dilorio connects the financial allegations to broader money laundering networks involving Russian ruble conversion (via SunGard), Net Element (NETE), and a 'shell factory' ecosystem, claiming the SEC facilitates these frauds instead of shutting them down.

The whistleblower asserts that his information has been used by the SEC/FINRA to bring selective complaints (e.g., against Sason, Keener, SeeThruEquity) while protecting the main perpetrator, NITE/VIRT, and that his rightful whistleblower awards have been wrongfully denied through procedural obstruction.
